titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Mary Johnson Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Christy Tomecek and staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday April 6, 2019 at 07:16

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

langmaterial.language: The material is in English and Spanish.

did.abstract: The papers document the activism and political work of New Haven activist Mary Johnson. The papers consist of activist organization files, subject files, correspondence, personal papers, and protest signs and posters. Materials address peace activism, healthcare reform, living wage initiatives, support for senior citizens, government elections, constitutional rights, environmental activism, and political parties. Organizations documented include the New Haven Federation of Teachers, Local 933, Greater New Haven Coalition for People, United Farm Workers (UFW), Progressive Action Roundtable, People Against Injustice (PAI), and Livable Income for Everyone (LIFE). Materials date from 1923 to 2015, with the bulk from 1975 to 2015.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in five series and one addition: I. Correspondence, 1975-2010. II. Personal and biographical files, 1923-2010. III. Activist organization files, 1969-2015. IV. Subject files, 1970-2015. V. Protest signs and posters, 1980-2012.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy of non-commercially produced items for their personal use should consult the ordering reproductions information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mary Johnson, 2016. Gift of Joan Cavanagh, 2017.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Mary Johnson Papers (MS 2050). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related material: Greater New Haven Coalition for People Records (MS 2007).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Mary Johnson was born Mary Elizabeth Doherty on March 29, 1922 in Winsted, Connecticut. Her father was a telegrapher for the Associated Press and her mother worked in the classified advertising department of the New Haven Register before marrying. Johnson was the oldest of four children. As a child, Johnson lived briefly in West Haven, Connecticut before moving to New Haven when she was six years old. In 1939, Johnson started college at the New Haven State Teacher's College and graduated in 1943. She taught elementary school for six years and resigned in June 1949 in anticipation of her December 26, 1949 marriage to Carl Johnson. They had three daughters before divorcing in 1977. Mary returned to teaching as a part time substitute teacher in 1965, and was reinstated as a full time teacher at the middle school level in 1967. She taught at Troup Middle School until her retirement until 1982.

Johnson became involved with advocacy and activism groups in the late 1950s, when she became interested in anti-nuclear energy efforts. However, it was the Vietnam War that pushed her to more intensive work for the peace movement in the 1960s. She regularly went to Washington, D.C. to protest the war and was involved in New Haven-based groups including Spinsters Opposed to Nuclear Genocide (SONG). She also joined the New Haven Federation of Teachers (NHFT), Local 933 in 1967. She served on their executive board until she retired. She was one of the leaders of the teachers' strikes in 1970 and 1975, despite court injunctions barring the strikes, and she was arrested both years. Her other union work included assisting with the United Farm Workers (UFW) national organizing teams for their boycotts of grapes and wine not produced by UFW workers.

After her retirement, Johnson formed a retiree chapter of Local 933. She also supported several labor union and labor history organizations, including the Greater New Haven Central Labor Council and the Greater New Haven Labor History Association. She also founded or was heavily involved with several organizations devoted to peace activism, healthcare reform, and living wage reform. These included the New Haven Coalition Against the War, the Coalition to Stop Trident, the Progressive Action Roundtable, Livable Income For Everyone (LIFE), the Greater New Haven Coalition for People, the Middle East Crisis Committee, and People Against Injustice. Johnson died in 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers document the activism and political work of New Haven activist Mary Johnson. The papers consist of activist organization files, subject files, correspondence, personal papers, and protest signs and posters. Activist organization files consist of newsletters, fliers, agendas, and minutes related to organizations that Mary Johnson either founded or participated with in a leadership role. These organizations focused on peace activism, organized labor, living wage initiatives, healthcare reform, and prison reform. Organizations documented include the New Haven Federation of Teachers, Local 933, Greater New Haven Coalition for People, United Farm Workers (UFW), Progressive Action Roundtable, People Against Injustice (PAI), and Livable Income for Everyone (LIFE).

Subject files include newsletters, fliers, pamphlets, and memoranda. Their materials address peace activism, healthcare reform, living wage initiatives, support for senior citizens, government elections, constitutional rights, environmental activism, and political parties. Many of the files are organized by topic. Some organizations that Johnson had an interest in but did not directly work for are included, such as the American Civil Liberties Union and Central Committee for Conscientious Objectors (CCCO).

Correspondence, personal and biographical files, and protest signs and posters comprise the remainder of the collection. They consist of personal correspondence, some organizational correspondence, awards, newspaper clippings, oral history transcripts, photographs of Johnson and her family, and signs and posters from protest and cultural events. Materials date from 1923 to 2015, with the bulk from 1975 to 2015.

controlaccess.subject: Labor unions -- United States
Peace movements
Health care reform
Social justice
controlaccess.corpname: Greater New Haven Coalition for People

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I mainly consists of personal correspondence. There is also material related to Johnson's imprisonment during the 1975 teachers' strike and her organizing work with the United Farm Workers (UFW).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is arranged alphabetically by topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II consists of papers and photographs pertaining to Johnson. The series also includes transcripts of an oral history she gave of her life, including her childhood, her time teaching, and her involvement with Local 933 and related events. Also included are additional interviews, newspaper articles, several calendars, and notes. Photographs are mostly of Johnson and her family and her 80th birthday party.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is arranged alphabetically by topic.

did.unittitle: Materials related to teacher's strike imprisonment
New Haven teacher's strike and related events
Retirement dinner for Mary Johnson's father, James Doherty
Project discussion paper on oral history interview with Mary Johnson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III consists of materials from organizations that Johnson was either an active participant in or a founder of. These organizations focus on organized labor, anti-war and peace activism, living wage initiatives, healthcare, and prison reform. The materials document daily business within the organizations, with a few specific campaigns pertaining to healthcare reform, bus stop locations, and financial security for low-income families. Materials include newsletters, minutes, agendas, pamphlets, fliers, newsclippings, and photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is arranged alphabetically by organization name and alphabetically therein.

George Gould, Gerry O'Donnell, Ronald Taylor

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes fliers, pamphlets, notes, correspondence, and newsletters related to specific topics or organizations of interest to Johnson and often involve local New Haven events. For organizations that Johnson actively participated in, please see Series III.

did.unittitle: Black history - photocopies from For the People: Black Socialists in the United States, Africa and the Caribbean

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of protest signs, posters, and fliers created by Johnson or others involved with her organizations or events. There are also posters and fliers advertising events in the New Haven area.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series V is arranged alphabetically by topic.

did.unittitle: Greater New Haven Coalition for People

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed program booklet and five DVDs from the memorial service for Mary Johnson, October 1, 2017.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The computer files are unprocessed and may contain sensitive information or be in a physical state that would prohibit use. Researchers wishing to request access should email mssa.assist@yale.edu . The request should outline the scope and purpose of the research project, why the researcher believes the material is relevant to their project, and contact information. If possible the request should also include a list of specific material of interest including collection, box, and folder numbers (or folder descriptions if folders are not numbered). The review may take several weeks.
